awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Novel Nanoelectronic Reconfigurable Synaptic Memory Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Intellectual Merit: 
The ability to perform low-power, extreme-scale, robust neuromorphic computing, inspired by a biological brain, has eluded the scientific community for a long time. A major roadblock lies in achieving the stringent power vs. area requirement for nanoelectronic devices to implement biologically inspired computational paradigms manifested by biological synapses on a silicon chip. The proposed research aims to develop ultra-low power synaptic memory devices based on doped transition metal oxide that can mimic the transient and steady-state dynamics of a biological synapse. This objective will be accomplished by executing the specific aims including: (1) development of synaptic memory devices based on doped HfO2 stacks, (2) development of bidirectional selector diode, and (3) study of integrated synaptic crossbar networks with Complementary Metal Oxide Semiconductor (CMOS) neurons as well as biological neurons. This research will present a platform device technology to achieve dynamic synaptic response in two-terminal devices fabricated using HfO2 by selective defect engineering through controlled doping, provide a fundamental understanding of the characteristic of defects responsible for synaptic behavior and device models, and extend the application of these device for synaptic computation and learning in neural circuits, neurophysiology, and finally the neuroengineering. The successful completion of this project will have transformative impact towards enabling low-power extreme-scale computing inspired by the massive parallelism of a biological-brain that has been identified as a scientific grand challenge by the US Department of Energy and National Academy of Engineering.

Broader Impacts: 
This project will strengthen collaborations with local small businesses and Semiconductor companies, which will have a significant impact on graduate and undergraduate training, workforce development, transition of research into advanced technology product, and regional economic growth. On educational front, the proposed research will train graduate and undergraduate students in the areas of micro/nano-electronic device fabrication, electrical testing, and data analysis and involve high-school girls in research through summer internship programs. The research findings will be tightly integrated in existing courses at graduate and undergraduate levels, and in the new course titled 'NanoScience for Electronic Era' that will be developed. As a part of this course, a teaching module on memristive devices will be developed with hands-on experiments that will be implemented in relevant courses at the University of Toledo and at Ohio Northern University which is primarily an undergraduate program school, and also made available openly for use at the other universities.  The participation of women in engineering will be encouraged through programs like 'Women in Science Day of Meeting (WISDOM)', and participation of other underrepresented groups in engineering will be encouraged by interacting with Toledo Public Schools and programs like 'Engineers for a Day' and 'Excel' at the University of Toledo. To reach out to the underrepresented groups of students (mostly Hispanic) in Ohio's rural communities, the PI will continue her involvement in the course titled 'Using Sustainable Engineering Activities to Teach Science', a distance-learning course that provides professional development and training to the teachers in rural Ohio who then teach mathematics and science to the children of migrant farm workers in Ohio. The results will be promptly disseminated to the scientific community through publications in peer-reviewed journals and conference presentations, and presented to general community through educational TV channel Plugged-In and YouTube videos.

por.por_cntn:
With the advent of Big Data, Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) algorithms have gained tremendous attention in the recent times. However, AI/ML algorithms are compute resource intensive and suffer from well-known memory-wall bottleneck which results in unacceptably long training and inferencing times. These limitations have led to the emergence of neuromorphic architectures where domain specific architectures are designed by incorporating high-bandwidth memories closer to the processing units to accelerate the ML algorithms. However, these systems are power hungry, expensive, and suffer from scalability issues. To address these limitations, truly brain-inspired architecture needs to be developed by developing bio-inspired components. In a biological brain, synaptic elements play a vital role in learning, decision making, and memory formation. The objective of this project was to develop nanoelectronic synaptic memory devices and study neuromorphic architectures with these devices. On intellectual merit side, the project outcome included the development of two-terminal and three-terminal gated synaptic memory devices. Two-terminal synaptic memory devices were developed using HfO2, Mn doped HfO2, Mg doped HfO2, SrTiO3, and NbOx based switching oxides. Three terminal gated-synaptic memory devices were developed using SrTiO3 and NbOx switching oxides. The gated synaptic memory devices offered benefits by providing opportunities to separate read and write terminals that helps in reducing the write power. Additionally, gate-terminal provided opportunities for implementing versatile sets of learning algorithms. We investigated both spike-based Hebbian unsupervised and supervised learning algorithms. The project also led to the observation of spike-frequency-based plasticity in these synaptic memory devices. The transport and switching mechanisms in these devices were studied. The devices were engineered both for filamentary and non-filamentary modes of switching. Transport studies were performed on both types of devices. In two-terminal devices, non-filamentary mode of switching was attributed to the oxygen-vacancies transport and changes in the contact resistances between switching oxide and electrode via a combination of trapping and de-trapping of electrons in these vacancies. Filamentary mode of switching was observed in HfO2 and Mg-doped HfO2 synaptic memory devices due to vacancies agglomeration leading to filament formation. Interestingly, non-filamentary mode of switching showed complex short-term plasticity on different time scales where the conductive states of the devices tended to decay over time after programming. Filamentary mode devices showed long-term retention of states over time. We developed preliminary neuromorphic architectures that can leverage both of these characteristics: devices with short-term plasticity were used for training while devices with long-term states were used for storing the trained weight values. Overall, these devices showed tremendous potential for developing low-power training and inferencing hardware for AI.

On broader impacts side, the project trained several graduate and undergraduate students in the areas of AI; ML; Neuromorphic Computers; Neuromimetic Devices; Advanced Logic and Memory device modeling, fabrication, and testing; Neural Circuit Design; and Neurocognitive Models for data analytics. Students were trained on nanofabrication tools in state of the art cleanroom fabrication facility, TCAD tools such as Verilog, Verilog-A, Synopsys, Cadence, Semiconductor Characterization tools such as Keithley 4200 Semiconductor Characterization System, Cascade Probestation, Lakeshore Cryogenic Probestation, and programming languages such as Python and C++, and processors such as GPU, and Arduino boards. These students are continuing to work in these area after graduating by joining leading semiconductors and software companies in the US. The project findings were published in high impact factor peer-reviewed journals and were also presented in various conferences. We performed several K-12 STEM outreach activities including hosting high-school girls for STEM summer workshops, preparing hands-on teaching modules for science teachers who teach kids of migrant farm workers in rural Ohio, establishing collaboration with Cincinnati Public Schools through Research Experiences for Teachers supplement and developing hands on teaching modules for middle school students and posting on YouTube in the areas of microelectronics and AI concepts.
